content.description: A chronic mental disorder characterized by persistent disturbances in thought, perception, emotions, and behavior, often including delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and impaired functioning.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Two or more of the following, each present for a significant portion of time during a 1-month period (or less if successfully treated), and at least one must be (1), (2), or (3): (1) delusions, (2) hallucinations, (3) disorganized speech, (4) grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, (5) negative symptoms. B. For a significant portion of the time since onset, level of functioning in one or more major areas (work, interpersonal relations, self-care) is markedly below the level achieved prior to onset. C. Continuous signs of disturbance persist for at least 6 months, with at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms. D. Schizoaffective disorder and mood disorder with psychotic features have been ruled out. E. Not attributable to a substance or another medical condition.
content.age_of_onset: Typically late adolescence to early 30s; earlier onset in males (late teens to early 20s) than females (mid-20s to early 30s).
content.prognosis: Variable course; about one-third achieve significant recovery, while others have persistent symptoms and functional impairment. Early intervention and consistent treatment improve long-term outcomes.

circuitry: Dysfunction in fronto-temporal-limbic circuits affecting cognition, perception, and emotional regulation.
neurochemistry: Dopamine dysregulation (mesolimbic hyperactivity linked to positive symptoms; mesocortical hypoactivity linked to negative symptoms).
Glutamatergic NMDA receptor hypofunction and GABAergic deficits.
structural_findings: Reduced gray matter volume in prefrontal and temporal cortices
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Heritability ~80%; environmental factors include prenatal infections, obstetric complications, early cannabis use, and psychosocial stress.

history_psychosocial: Detailed timeline of psychotic symptoms, prodromal changes, and functional decline.
Family psychiatric history and psychosocial stressors.
medical_assessment: Rule out substance-induced psychosis and medical causes (thyroid, neurologic, infectious).
Basic labs, urine toxicology, neuroimaging if indicated.
risk_stratification: Suicide risk is elevated, especially early in illness and after discharge.
Assess aggression risk in acute psychosis.
differential_diagnosis: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
evaluation.team_and_process: Multidisciplinary approach with psychiatry, psychology, social work, and occupational therapy.

core: Negative symptoms (avolition, alogia, anhedonia, flat affect)

severity_levels.mild: Symptoms present but partially compensated; functioning impaired but some independence maintained.
severity_levels.moderate: Ongoing symptoms with significant impairment in work, social, and self-care domains.
severity_levels.severe: Severe psychosis or negative symptoms with profound functional disability.

biological: Family history of schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders

impact_on_life.school_work: Decline in academic/work performance due to disorganization, cognitive deficits, and social withdrawal.
impact_on_life.social: Relationship strain from odd behavior, paranoia, or withdrawal.
impact_on_life.medical: Side effects from antipsychotic medications (metabolic syndrome, movement disorders).
impact_on_life.emotional: Frustration, hopelessness, or lack of motivation.

medications: Antipsychotics: first-generation (haloperidol, fluphenazine) and second-generation (risperidone, olanzapine, aripiprazole, clozapine for treatment-resistant cases)
neuromodulation: ECT for severe catatonia or depression

treatment_goals: Reduce severity and frequency of psychotic episodes.
Improve functioning and quality of life.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing early psychotic symptoms to depression, anxiety, or substance use without longitudinal assessment.
Failing to recognize subtle prodromal changes.
overdiagnosis_factors: Misinterpreting transient stress-induced psychosis as schizophrenia.
Confusing mood disorder with psychotic features for primary psychotic disorder.

specifiers.first_episode: First episode of psychosis meeting full criteria.
specifiers.multiple_episodes: Two or more episodes, with or without residual symptoms.
specifiers.continuous: Symptoms meet criteria throughout the majority of the illness course.

warning_signs: Progressive social withdrawal and decline in functioning.
Emergence of fixed false beliefs or hallucinations.
Marked disorganization in speech or behavior.

adolescents: Social isolation, academic decline, odd beliefs; may have more abrupt onset.
adults: Chronic course with periods of exacerbation and remission.
older_adults: Possible late-onset cases; more likely to have paranoid symptoms and less severe negative symptoms.

real_life_examples: A 20-year-old college student begins withdrawing from friends, neglecting hygiene, and expressing beliefs that classmates are spying on them; symptoms persist over six months with functional decline.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek urgent evaluation for psychosis, inability to care for self, or suicidal/homicidal thoughts.
